purposes of website accessibilityThe Lofton, affordable apartments, open on south side by Erin SimonekThu, November 6, 2025 at 5:32 PM8VIEW ALL PHOTOSThe apartment is located off of S. High St. and Fornof Rd. The project features "thoughtfully designed homes serving households earning between 30% and 80% of the Area Median Income (AMI)." Monthly rental rates range from $1,295-$1,994. November 6, 2025. (WSYX)Comment on this story1CommentShare storySharetopics: The LoftonAffordable housingColumbusSouth SideNRP GroupCommunity Development for All PeoplePublic-private partnershipFamily apartmentsCOLUMBUS, Ohio (WSYX) — More than half of the 245 units at the newly opened The Lofton already have been leased by perspective residents. Leaders in the City of Columbus, the NRP Group, and faith-based nonprofit Community Development for All People celebrated the completion and grand opening of The Lofton, a family-focused housing community in Columbus’s South High neighborhood.
"This is a great public-private partnership," Mayor Andrew Ginther said Thursday. "We were thrilled to be able to invest city bond dollars that had been approved by the voters previously on this project." The apartment is located off of South High Street and Fornof Road. The project features "thoughtfully designed homes serving households earning between 30% and 80% of the Area Median Income (AMI)." Monthly rental rates range from $1,295-$1,994.The apartments offer a fitness center, community room and spaces for gatherings and recreation. Outdoor areas feature walkable paths throughout the property, a playground and landscaped open spaces designed for interaction and daily activity. The Lofton was designed by MA Design, a women-owned Columbus firm with a 45-year history specializing in family-oriented and affordable housing. Apartments feature fully equipped kitchens, modern cabinetry, luxury vinyl plank flooring, and walk-in closets. Residents will have access to onsite parking, elevators, package concierge services and laundry facilities, according to a press release sent to ABC 6. Columbus City Council President Shannon Hardin told the crowd Thursday he grew up right around the corner from The Lofton."What is really exciting about this project is that it's in the heart of the south side," Hardin told ABC 6. "This community continues to grow. This used to be on the side of a former Chinese restaurant. To now see it be transformed into housing shows what we can do when we stack hands."The apartment's opening comes just after Columbus voters approved a $1.9 million bond package, along with a $500 million affordable housing bond, to further expand affordable housing access in the city. Comment with BubblesREAD THE COMMENTS (1)"We're excited about the opportunity to bring more projects like this to neighborhoods throughout the city," Ginther added.
